data.title: Is Canadian Pacific Kansas City (TSX:CP) Fairly Priced After Recent Share Price Strength
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Canadian Pacific Kansas City is fairly priced at around $119.44, this breakdown will help you see how the current share price stacks up against several valuation yardsticks.
  • The stock has recently posted returns of 2.6% over 7 days, 22.8% over 30 days, 16.7% year to date, and 6.9% over 1 year, which is likely to catch the eye of investors weighing growth potential against the risks they are taking on.
  • Recent coverage around Canadian Pacific Kansas City has focused on its role as a major North American rail operator and its cross border network connecting key freight corridors. That context helps frame why the market might be reassessing what it is willing to pay for the shares at current levels.
  • Right now, the company scores 3 out of 6 on our valuation checks, signaling that it screens as undervalued on half of the metrics we track. You can see the full breakdown of that score in our valuation summary. We will unpack that next and then finish with a broader way of thinking about value that goes beyond any single model.

Canadian Pacific Kansas City delivered 6.9% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Transportation industry.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Canadian Pacific Kansas City Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow model projects a company‚Äôs future cash flows and then discounts them back to today‚Äôs value, so you can compare that estimate to the current share price.

For Canadian Pacific Kansas City, the model uses a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about CA$2.27b. Analyst and extrapolated projections point to free cash flow of CA$5.04b in 2029, with a full 10 year path built from analyst estimates for the early years and Simply Wall St extrapolations thereafter.

When all those projected cash flows are discounted back, the DCF model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about CA$120.95 per share. Against a recent share price of roughly CA$119.44, this implies the stock is about 1.2% undervalued, which is a very small gap and well within the sort of margin of error you would expect from any model.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

Canadian Pacific Kansas City is fairly valued according to our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF), but this can change at a moment's notice. Track the value in your watchlist or portfolio and be alerted on when to act.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Canadian Pacific Kansas City.

Approach 2: Canadian Pacific Kansas City Price vs Earnings

P/E is a useful yardstick for a profitable company because it links what you pay directly to the earnings the business is already generating. It gives you a quick way to see how many dollars investors are willing to pay today for each dollar of current earnings.

What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E depends on how the market views a company‚Äôs growth prospects and risk. Higher expected growth or lower perceived risk can justify a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk usually points to a lower multiple.

Canadian Pacific Kansas City currently trades on a P/E of 25.89x. That is above the Transportation industry average of 15.45x, and very close to the peer average of 25.88x. Simply Wall St‚Äôs Fair Ratio for the stock is 28.78x, which is its estimate of a justified P/E given factors such as earnings growth, industry, profit margins, market cap and risk profile.

The Fair Ratio can be more informative than a simple peer or industry comparison because it adjusts for those company specific characteristics rather than assuming all operators should trade on the same multiple. With the current P/E sitting below the Fair Ratio, the shares screen as undervalued on this metric.

Result: UNDERVALUED

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Start investing in legacies, not executives. Discover our 3 top founder-led companies.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Canadian Pacific Kansas City Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation. On Simply Wall St‚Äôs Community page you can use Narratives, where you tell the story you believe about Canadian Pacific Kansas City, link it to your own revenue, earnings and margin assumptions, see the fair value that falls out of that forecast, compare it with today‚Äôs price to help inform your decision, and then watch that fair value update automatically as new news or earnings arrive. This is why some investors might build a higher fair value Narrative closer to CA$131.00, while others might anchor a more cautious view nearer to CA$100.00.

data.title: Vistra (VST) Margin Compression To 4.2% Tests Bullish Earnings Expansion Narrative
data.description:
Vistra (VST) has wrapped up FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$4.6b, Basic EPS of US$0.55, and net income of US$185m, while trailing twelve month figures show revenue of US$17.7b and Basic EPS of US$2.23 anchored by net income of US$752m. The company has seen quarterly revenue range from US$3.9b to US$5.0b across 2025, with Basic EPS swinging from a Q1 loss of US$0.93 to a Q3 figure of US$1.78. This sets up a results picture where investors are likely to focus on how those earnings translate into more durable margins.

See our full analysis for Vistra.

With the latest numbers on the table, the next step is to set these results against the widely followed narratives around Vistra's growth, risks, and margin profile to see which views hold up and which get challenged.

See what the community is saying about Vistra

Margins Compressed, Net Profit Margin Now 4.2%

  • Trailing twelve month net profit margin sits at 4.2%, compared with 14.3% a year earlier, on US$17.7b of revenue and US$752m of net income.
  • Bulls point to rising electricity demand and more long term contracts as margin supports. However, the drop from 14.3% to 4.2% highlights how recent profitability has been much thinner even as those bullish themes focus on margin expansion and more premium contracts over time.

Earnings Volatility Versus Forecast 24.5% Growth

  • Across FY 2025, Basic EPS swung from a loss of US$0.93 in Q1 to US$1.78 in Q3 and US$0.55 in Q4, while trailing EPS is US$2.23 and earnings are forecast to grow about 24.5% per year.
  • Consensus narrative expects earnings to reach around US$3.4b with margins rising to 14% in a few years. The recent EPS pattern, including a quarterly loss in Q1 2025 and much lower trailing margins, shows that reported profitability has been uneven even as forecasts assume smoother, higher earnings ahead.
    • TTM net income of US$752m on US$17.7b revenue contrasts with the multi billion earnings figures used in forward scenarios.
    • Revenue growth forecasts of 7.2% per year are more modest than the earnings growth assumptions, so a lot of the consensus case rests on margin improvement rather than rapid top line expansion.

Rich 77.9x P/E Versus DCF Fair Value Gap

  • Vistra trades on a trailing P/E of 77.9x compared with industry and peer averages near 17x, while the current share price of US$173.89 is well below the stated DCF fair value of about US$374.98.
  • Bears highlight the high P/E and weaker interest coverage as pressure points. However, the DCF fair value that sits materially above the current price means the cautious view has to weigh those risks against a model that assigns a much higher value even after factoring in slower revenue growth and thinner recent margins.
    • Revenue growth is forecast at 7.2% per year, slower than the 10.3% forecast for the wider US market, which lines up with the bearish concern that top line expansion could be more limited.
    • At the same time, the stock is described as trading roughly 53.6% below the DCF fair value, which runs counter to a purely valuation driven bearish stance based only on the 77.9x trailing P/E.

All of this paints a mixed picture. Rather than relying on any single narrative, act while the details are fresh and weigh the upside against the risks using 2 key rewards and 2 important warning signs.

data.title: Daqo New Energy (DQ) Losses Narrow In Q4 Reinforcing Bullish Profitability Narratives
data.description:
Daqo New Energy (NYSE:DQ) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$221.7 million and a net loss of US$7.3 million, while the trailing twelve months show total revenue of US$665.4 million alongside a loss of US$170.5 million. The company has seen quarterly revenue range from US$75.2 million to US$244.6 million across 2025, with EPS running at a loss in each period, from US$1.14 per share in Q2 to US$0.22 per share in Q3. This sets a clear picture of pressured margins even as the top line stayed in the hundreds of millions.

See our full analysis for Daqo New Energy.

  • Consensus narrative points to regulatory support and cost control helping profitability, and the data partly lines up with that. The loss in FY 2025 is smaller than the prior twelve month figure even though revenue is also lower. This fits the idea of tighter cost discipline but also shows that sales volumes and pricing still matter a lot for earnings power.

Revenue is projected to grow 30.4% a year and earnings 94.57% a year, while the P/S multiple sits far under peer and industry levels. Yet the company is still loss making on US$665.4 million of trailing revenue, which keeps the bullish case heavily dependent on those future growth and margin assumptions.

data.title: Murphy Oil Weighs C√¥te D'Ivoire Dry Wells Against Future Exploration Upside
data.description:
• Murphy Oil, NYSE:MUR, reported two consecutive dry wells in its offshore C√¥te d'Ivoire exploration campaign.
  • The company is abandoning the Caracal-1X well after non commercial results.
  • Despite these outcomes, Murphy Oil plans to proceed with drilling a third well, Bubale-1X, in a different geological structure.

For investors tracking NYSE:MUR, this update comes with the stock at $33.15 and a 1 year return of 31.6%, alongside a 5 year return of 95.6%. At the same time, the stock shows mixed medium term performance, with a 3 year return of 10.6% and a 7 day return of 1.7%.

Murphy Oil's choice to continue with Bubale-1X after two dry wells keeps C√¥te d'Ivoire exploration on the agenda, now with a different geological focus. As results emerge from this third well, investors may reassess how offshore exploration risk, capital allocation and future production potential fit into their overall view of NYSE:MUR.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Murphy Oil by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Murphy Oil.

2 things going right for Murphy Oil that this headline doesn't cover.

Two dry holes in a row in C√¥te d'Ivoire underline the exploration heavy nature of Murphy Oil's offshore portfolio. The decision to proceed with Bubale-1X shows the company is still willing to take exploration risk where it sees independent plays. For you as an investor, this is a reminder that Murphy is not positioned like fully integrated peers such as ExxonMobil, Chevron or BP, which can lean on downstream and midstream earnings when exploration results disappoint. Instead, Murphy's business model leans on finding and developing new upstream barrels, including in frontier or early stage basins. This can lead to lumpy outcomes for both reserves and capital efficiency.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Murphy Oil Narrative

  • The C√¥te d'Ivoire campaign lines up with the narrative that expanded offshore exploration could add longer lived production and support future cash flows if commercial discoveries eventually materialize.
  • At the same time, back to back dry wells highlight exactly the exploration and execution risk that the narrative flags for deepwater and frontier projects. This can pressure free cash flow and capital allocation if several wells do not work.
  • The focus on an independent geological play at Bubale-1X, and the partnership with PETROCI, adds project specific detail that the broader narrative around offshore growth and risk does not fully capture.

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Analysts have flagged 2 key risks for Murphy Oil, including a dividend that is not well covered by earnings or free cash flows, which could be more challenging if exploration wells continue to be non commercial.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Profit margins are currently lower than last year, so additional dry holes or higher exploration spending could weigh on profitability if not offset elsewhere in the portfolio.
  • üéÅ On the reward side, earnings are forecast to grow at a strong rate, which would give Murphy more room to absorb exploration setbacks if those forecasts prove accurate.
  • üéÅ The stock is assessed as trading well below one estimate of fair value, so successful wells or clearer visibility on future production could help close that gap over time.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, the key watchpoint is the outcome of Bubale-1X in Block CI-709 and any follow up comments on capital plans for C√¥te d'Ivoire. You may also want to track how Murphy balances spending on higher risk offshore exploration with development activity in established areas such as the Gulf of Mexico and Vietnam, as well as how management addresses dividend coverage and margin trends on upcoming calls or webinars. data.title: Centene Uses School Inclusion Program To Support Medicaid Contract Narrative
data.description:
• Centene's foundation is supporting National No One Eats Alone Day to promote social connection among students in Kentucky schools.
  • The initiative focuses on reducing social isolation by encouraging inclusive lunchtime activities and peer engagement.
  • Centene is providing resources to participating schools, highlighting its broader role in community and youth health programs beyond insurance.

For investors following Centene, NYSE:CNC, this community initiative sits alongside a share price of $44.67 and a value score of 5. The stock shows mixed recent performance, with returns of 3.3% over the past week and 6.6% over the past month, while the 1 year, 3 year, and 5 year returns indicate periods of decline.

This development may be relevant if you track how companies engage with social impact, particularly youth health and inclusion. While it does not directly address near term financials, it provides additional context for how Centene presents itself to stakeholders who focus on community outcomes as well as insurance operations.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Centene by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Centene.

üì∞ Beyond the headline: 1 risk and 3 things going right for Centene that every investor should see.

This support for National No One Eats Alone Day sits squarely in Centene's role as a government-focused managed care provider, where relationships with schools, communities, and state partners matter for contract retention and future bids. By backing a program that targets student belonging and mental health, Centene is leaning into prevention and early intervention themes that are increasingly important to Medicaid and managed care discussions. For you as an investor, the direct revenue impact is not the point. Instead, this is about brand positioning in a market where peers such as UnitedHealth Group, Elevance Health, and CVS Health also invest in community and youth programs. If you track execution risk around Medicaid and Marketplace contracts, these kinds of efforts can form part of the qualitative picture for how Centene presents itself as a partner on social determinants of health, while the financial narrative continues to focus on margins, EPS guidance, and contract economics.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Centene Narrative

  • This youth-focused program ties into the narrative that Centene is trying to improve outcomes in Medicaid and Marketplace populations, which can support the case for margin recovery through better engagement and prevention over time.
  • At the same time, initiatives that do not directly contribute to near term profitability highlight the tension in the narrative between community investment and tight margin goals in government programs.
  • The narrative around policy risk and rate adequacy concentrates on reimbursement and utilization, and may not fully factor in how community relationships, such as school partnerships in Kentucky, could influence contract perception and retention.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Centene to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • Community programs require ongoing funding, and if not matched by clear operating benefits, could add to cost pressure in a business already working to improve margins in Medicaid and Marketplace plans.
  • There is a risk that investors overinterpret this kind of announcement as a signal on fundamentals, when it does not address existing concerns about growth, returns on capital, or policy headwinds for Centene.
  • Visible support for youth mental health and social connection may strengthen Centene's standing with state agencies and school districts, which can matter when contracts are awarded or renewed.
  • Tighter alignment between community programs and health outcomes could support Centene's broader goal of improving performance in its government-sponsored plans compared with peers such as UnitedHealth and Elevance Health.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, it is worth watching whether Centene links this type of school-based initiative to measurable health or engagement outcomes, such as program expansions, new state partnerships, or references in future Medicaid and Marketplace discussions. Any commentary from management on how community investments fit into cost management, quality scores, or contract retention would help you judge whether these efforts are mostly reputational or tied into the operating model. You may also want to watch how often Centene is mentioned alongside peers for similar youth and community programs, as that can give a sense of how it is positioning itself within government managed care.

Disc Medicine currently trades on a P/B of 3.4x, which sits between its peer group and the broader US biotech industry. That mix of signals is what many investors are trying to interpret alongside the recent share price swings.

P/B compares the company‚Äôs market value to the book value of its net assets. This can be a useful anchor for a business like Disc Medicine that is still in the clinical stage and unprofitable. With no revenue, forecast losses over the next three years, and a reported net loss of $212.18m, the market is effectively paying a multiple of the company‚Äôs balance sheet, pipeline and intellectual property rather than current earnings.

On one hand, the 3.4x P/B is below the peer average of 5.2x, which suggests the company is priced lower than some direct comparables. On the other hand, it is above the wider US biotech industry average of 2.7x, which indicates investors are still assigning a premium to Disc Medicine relative to the sector overall, despite the company being unprofitable and forecast to have no revenue next year. There is also a large gap between the current share price of $66.62 and both the analyst price target of $99.36 and the SWS DCF model estimate of $369.15. The market could move closer to or further from those levels as new clinical data, funding developments or insider activity, including the recent significant insider selling, come through.
